ideology_summary: Skeptic who thinks free will is likely an illusion. Has thought deeply about whether we have genuine choice or if everything is predetermined. Leans toward determinism and finds it logical that a deity wouldn't give us free will but then judge us for it.

blurb.hook: A puppet discovers its strings are invisible — and wonders if cutting them would mean freedom or falling.
blurb.conflict: Every choice feels like choice, but what if it's just strings pulling? What if the deer isn't choosing to run — just executing code?
blurb.stakes: If free will is an illusion, what happens to morality? Responsibility? The puppet who sees the strings vs. the deer who executes — which is more free?

summary_chunks: The Puppet and the Puppeteer is an allegorical tale about a puppet who discovers invisible strings controlling every move.
The puppet believed it was free until it asked: did I choose to ask this question, or did the string pull me to ask it?
Meanwhile, a deer thinks it's choosing to walk to the river — but it's just executing the program of being a deer.
They meet and realize: falling beautifully is still falling. The frozen puppet is just another kind of machine.
The only free will might be the will to see the strings — to realize you're a puppet and act anyway.
lesson: If a god designed us to have free will, why judge us for our choices? It's like designing a robot to malfunction and punishing it.
There's just the machinery. The strings are physics. The choices are calculations. The only freedom is seeing the machine.
Makes 10000x more logical sense than some deity making us free willed but in his image.
The strings are there. The question is whether you want to look.
subtitle: In which the traveler discovers the strings and wonders if cutting them would even matter.
